results.title: Kim and Harley and the kids
results.creator_credit: Flying Carpet Films, Steve Thomas and Katrina Sawyer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Family foibles”.
Part of the “Family foibles” series of documentaries about five Australian families. Kim and Harley are an impoverished couple living in a Ministry of Housing estate in outer Melbourne with their four little girls, including their 4-year old twins and 12-year old Gabby, the eldest, Kim’s child from an earlier marriage. By pawning their possessions, selling scrap metal and accepting food donations from charity organisations, they barely manage to make ends meet. Their circumstances are made more difficult by the fact that Kim suffers from hepatitis C and high levels of stress. While the family demonstrates great resourcefulness, humour and patience to survive below the poverty line, their hardships cause tensions to erupt regularly into aggressive shouting matches which occasionally become physically violent. A confronting portrait of a family with no support which confounds all simplistic explanations of poverty. A study guide is available from http://www.roninfilms.com.au/related/2365104851-0.pdf

results.title: Kim / by Rudyard Kipling
results.creator_credit: London Film Productions, David Conroy and John Davies
results.brief_description: Rudyard Kipling’s classic tale of the orphaned son of a British soldier in India at the time of the British Raj is here brought to the screen with great enthusiasm. Kim and his horseman friend who belongs to the British secret service experience many adventures. These adventures eventually lead him into a friendship with a Buddhist lama in search of the river which sprang from the ground when the Lord Buddha shot an arrow, so he joins him in his quest, as he too searches for his own origins. Stars Peter O’Toole and Bryan Brown.

results.title: Kim's looking glass: new baby at home
results.brief_description: Tells the story of how a girl uses a magic mirror to reverse things to the way they were before the birth of her baby sister. Shows how loneliness and jealousy are natural reactions of children to having a new baby in the family.

results.brief_description: A man and a woman literally tear strips off each other and uncover some nasty home truths. Innovative claymation about romance, false expectations and misconceived ideals.

results.title: Killing us softly: advertising's image of women
results.creator_credit: Cambridge Documentary Films, Jean Kilbourne, Joseph Vitagliano and Patricia Stallone
results.brief_description: Using hundreds of examples from magazines, newspapers, album covers and store-front windows, this film exposes the psychological and sexual schemes that underlie many advertising campaigns. With an intriguing mixture of statistics, humour, insight and outrage, Jean Kilbourne shows her audience that although individual advertisements may seem harmless by themselves, they add up to a powerful form of cultural conditioning.
results.title_for_label: Killing us softly: advertising’s image of women
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cambridge Documentary Films, Jean Kilbourne, Joseph Vitagliano and Patricia Stallone

results.title: Killing Priscilla
results.creator_credit: Film Finance Corporation Australia, A Great Scott, Jane Scott and Lizzy Gardiner
results.brief_description: Not so very long ago, Stephan Elliott wrote and directed a movie called ‘The Adventures of Priscilla Queen of the Desert’ - a low-budget film that proved to be a worldwide smash grossing over a hundred million dollars at the box office. Four years and one flop (‘Welcome to Woop Woop’) later, Elliott is making ‘Eye of the beholder’ a film with a twelve million dollar budget, and an impressive cast which includes Ewan McGregor, k.d. lang, Ashley Judd and Jason Priestley. The storyline promises action-adventure in nine American cities across four different seasons. The financing has been done outside the studio system - through a team of sales agents who want a profit - or else, adding undue pressure to the project. Enter Lizzy Gardiner. Academy Award-winning costume designer and friend of Elliott’s for more than twenty years. In addition to bringing her expertise as a costume designer, Gardina also brings a Sony 1000 DVC camera, and in a moment of insanity Elliott gives her permission to document the whole process. What transpires is a no-holds-barred account of the reality of commercial filmmaking in the late 1990s: a study in passion, power, madness and lies.

results.title: Killing of a Chinese bookie
results.brief_description: “The Killing of a Chinese Bookie” presents a portrait of a man who is so self-sufficient that he cannot become personally involved with anyone. Cosmo Vitelli, played by Ben Gazzara, is a nightclub owner who believes in conducting his personal and business affairs with plenty of flair and professionalism. When the mob threatens him he works desperately to save his face and the club.

results.title: Killing ground
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Simon Target
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Academy”.
The Killing ground looks at the physical and moral challenges in training the cadets. The cadets are starting to come to terms with the reality of the fitness training they are undertaking, training which comes before any academic study. This episode also focuses on how the female cadets are adjusting to a predominately male facility. Two girls, terrified of heights, are put to the test on an exercise to bring them to face to face with their fear. Kizzy reveals that because she has injured her foot in training and has no arch left in her left foot she may not be able to graduate. After spending three years at the academy - she may be discharged as physically unfit.

results.title: Killing farm rats
results.brief_description: Portrays methods of killing rats on a large farm in Scotland. Chemical methods of control, such as gassing and pre-baiting are priveleged, but information on the long term deterence of rats is also provided.

results.title: Killers in Eden
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Granada International Productions, ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit and Klaus Toft
results.brief_description:
‘Killers in Eden’ is the story of perhaps the most extraordinary partnership ever forged between humans and wild animals. Locals in the Australian town of Eden claim that beginning in the mid-1800s an intimate and co-operative relationship developed between human whalers and killer whales.

The giant prey whales - minke whales, humpbacks, right whales, blue whales - were herded into Twofold Bay by the killer whales. This allowed the shore-based human whalers to close in for the kill. Working together in Eden, man and beast were able to do something neither could have managed on their own; killing the largest whales on earth. The two hunters then shared the spoils through an arrangement known as the ‘Law of the Tongue’.

Whale enthusiast Greg Mckee, who has researched this story for 15 years, joins forces with eminent zoologist Danielle Clode to investigate the intimate details of the relationship. Together, Greg and Danielle reveal not only the fascinating details of how the partnership began, but also why it tragically ended. A Co-production with Granada International.
